abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Petroleum Exploration
            and Development Technical Assistance Project is rated as
            highly satisfactory, sustainability as highly likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, bank
            performance as highly satisfactory, and borrower performance
            as satisfactory. The main lessons learned from the project
            include: Objectives that are extraneous to the implementing
            agency's responsibilities should not be included, for
            instance, inclusion of standards for storage, handling and
            transportation of petroleum products. Objectives should not
            suggest or prescribe modalities of development at too early
            a stage, for instance, framing studies for commercial gas
            development by Liquefied Natural Gas export (without
            including other development scenarios). Systems and
            procedures for project management and implementation should
            be in place before the commencement of the project and
            should be maintained. Their usage should be closely
            monitored throughout the project to ensure acceptable
            standards of project implementation. Organized
            implementation of project activities through defined
            documentation such as the Project Task Form is most useful
            for management control. Contacts for goods and services
            should, as far as possible, be denominated in the currency
            of the loan to avoid impacts from exchange rate fluctuations
            and consequent costs variations.
